metadata.description: This is the Hachik≈ç Memorial Statue in Tokyo. It is between the subway station and Shibuya Scramble Crossing.
I took this at 8:30 am at the Shibuya Scramble Crossing in Tokyo. I was a little underwhelmed, but I'm guessing that it would be different at 8:30 pm.
I took this near the Ryu'o-sha Shrine in Nara. The deer in Nara are really friendly (for the most part).
I took this at the Fushimi Inari Taisha Shinto shrine in Kyoto. It dates from 711 A.D. and features a path with hundreds of traditional gates. There were a heck of a lot of people here.
I took this at the Kiyomizu-dera Buddhist temple on Mount Otowa.
I took this at the Meiji Jingu Shinto shrine in Shibuya. Tokyo was super hot that day, and I was guzzling Pocari Sweat to get through the shrine's grounds.

I took this at the Meiji Jingu Shinto shrine in Shibuya. I saw this type of elevated threshold a lot when I was in China. Two things that I was told were that it is disrespectful to step on it and that it is there to keep out evil spirits.
I took this at the Ry≈çgoku JR Station in Tokyo. It's next to the Ryogoku Kokugikan National Sumo Arena, and on the way out of the station, there is a lot of sumo-related stuff on the walls.
This is the Great Buddha of Nara in Daibutsuden Hall at the T≈çdaiji complex. It stands 15 meters high and depicts the Roshana Buddha.
I took this at the Majang Reservoir when I visited the demilitarized zone. There is a suspension bridge over the reservoir and a lovely set of walking trails around it.
I took this at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall, looking down towards the Liberty Square Arch. There was a storm on it's way in when I took this.
I took this at the Ryogoku Kokugikan National Sumo Arena in Tokyo. I was in town for the Tokyo Grand Sumo Tournament and managed to get a ticket.

This is the "Bridge of Freedom." It crosses a lake at Imjingak Pyeonghwa Nuri Park. Initially, the Bridge had two spans that headed up and down, but they were destroyed by bombing, and only the pier remained. Later, the west Bridge was restored to exchange prisoners of war, and a temporary bridge was installed at the south end. 13,000 POWs were exchanged on it.

This is the Comfort Woman Memorial at Imjingak Pyeonghwa Nuri Park. The empty chair represents the women who have since died. There are two memorials because one is intended to be in the north in the future.
I took this at the Atomic Bomb Dome in Hiroshima. It was originally the Hiroshima Prefectural Industrial Promotion Hall.
I took this at the Atomic Bomb Dome in Hiroshima. It was originally the Hiroshima Prefectural Industrial Promotion Hall.
I took this at Lungshan Temple in Taipei. Returning home from Seoul, I had a 24-hour layover and wanted to see what I could. I managed to catch this temple before the weather got dreadful.
I took this at Lungshan Temple in Taipei. Returning home from Seoul, I had a 24-hour layover and wanted to see what I could. I managed to catch this temple before the weather got dreadful.
After a long day in Kyoto, I took this at the Arashiyama Bamboo Forest, a little to the north of the entrance to Tenryu-ji Temple.
I took this at Kinkaku-ji temple in Kyoto. This Zen temple in northern Kyoto has two floors completely covered in gold leaf.
This is the Kiyomizu-dera Sanjunoto in Kyoto. The three-story pagoda at Kiyomizu-dera is 31 meters high and one of the tallest in Japan.

I took this at the Kiyomizu-dera Amidado Buddhist temple in Kyoto. The temple was initially associated with the Hosso sect, one of the oldest schools within Japanese Buddhism, but formed its own Kita Hosso sect in 1965. In 1994, the temple was added to the list of World Heritage Sites.
I took this near the Jukkoku Bridge in Kyoto.
I took this from the top of the Enoshima Sea Candle on the small tidal island of Enoshima.
This is the Kamakura Daibutsu at Kotoku-in in Kamakura. It was swelteringly hot there, but I still paid to climb into the Buddha.

I took this at the New Dora Observatory, along the DMZ in South Korea. The original Dora Observatory, which this one replaces, was just a few yards from the bus. They asked us not to photograph it because it is part of an active military installation. The line you can see going through the image is the South Korean side of the DMZ.
The baby deer would like a cracker.
I was lucky enough to get tickets for the Grand Tournament at the Ryogoku Kokugikan National Sumo Arena. Most of my photos of the matches could be clearer, but the seats weren't great.
I was lucky enough to get tickets for the Grand Tournament at the Ryogoku Kokugikan National Sumo Arena. Most of my photos of the matches could be clearer, but the seats weren't great.
I took this on the first night I was in Tokyo. I went for a late-night walk around Akihabara and took this on the way back to the hotel.
I took this near the Nonomiya Shrine in Kyoto. It was later in the day, and the sun was starting to go down.
I took this in 2018 in Suzhou. It was my first time in Asia.
Do you intervene? Left them fight? ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è
This is the Great Buddha Hall in Nara. Emperor Shomu ordered the monk-architect Roben to build a temple at Nara between 728 and 749.

This is the Golden Pavilion in Kyoto. It has burned down numerous times throughout its history, including twice during the Onin War, a civil war that destroyed much of Kyoto, and once again, more recently, in 1950, when a monk set it on fire. The present structure was rebuilt in 1955.
This is the Grand Buddha at Ling Shan. It was completed at the end of 1996 and is 88 meters tall.

I took this at the Temple of Heaven. Located south of the Forbidden City on the east side of Yongnei Dajie, the original Altar of Heaven and Earth was completed together with the Forbidden City in 1420, the eighteenth year of the reign of the Ming Emperor Yongle.
Seoul has you if you are up for Chicago Pizza or Belgian Waffles.
This is the Gwangmyeongmun Gate at Deoksugung Palace.
This is the Bosingak Bell Pavilion in Jongno 2-ga, Jongno-gu.
I took this at the Ryogoku Kokugikan National Sumo Arena during the 2024 Grand Tournament. New career?
This was directly across the street from my hotel in Akasaka.
I took this on the overnight ferry between Osaka and Busan.

I took this the day after I went to the Sumo matches. The guy next to me at the matches talked about how he was offered horse meat and rejected it. I couldn't get horse meat out of my mind, so I found Umakabai!, which serves horse sashimi.
I took this at the Hasedera Buddhist temple in Kamakura. I remember seeing prayer wheels like this when I was in Nepal.
This is fast food in Jiaxing. I took this at a truck stop in Xiuzhou District.
I took this in the Chuo Ward in Osaka.
This was my first day in Osaka, and Glica Man was on my list of places to visit.
I took this at the Hasedera Buddhist temple in Kamakura. Hasedera (Èï∑Ë∞∑ÂØ∫) is a temple of the Jodo sect, famous for its eleven-headed statue of Kannon, the goddess of mercy.
After attending the Tokyo Grand Sumo Tournament, we went to Hana no Mai Restaurant to eat the type of dinner that sumo wrestlers eat. It was a lot of food.
I took this in the fall of 2019. We stayed in the port city of Tangier and took a day trip into the mountains. I remember loving this lunch.
I took this while being guided through Chefchaouen. I have never seen oranges look so good.
I took this on the Pont d'I√©na in 2019, on my way to the Tour Eiffel.
This is the Meiji Jingu Ichino Torii at the Meiji Jingu Shinto shrine. It was ridiculously hot outside when I was there.
I took this while rushing through Namba Walk early in the morning.
I took this late in the day in the Arashiyama Bamboo Forest in Kyoto.
I took this image at Shree Kaal Bhairav Temple while visiting Durbar Square in Kathmandu.
I took this outside of the Kasugataisha Shrine in the Mt. Kasuga Primeval Forest.
I heard that purchasing a lantern for the Shinto shrine is costly, but you should consider buying one in your lifetime to help support it.
I took this at Lungshan Temple in Taipei. The temple was built in 1740 during the Qing Dynasty.
I captured this at Deoksugung Palace on my last day in Seoul. It had been raining quite a bit, but the weather cleared up enough for me to explore it.

I took this at Swayambhu Mahachaitya (also called the "Monkey Temple") in Kathmandu. Believed to date back to 460 A.D., it was built by King Manadeva, and by the 13th century, it had become an important center of Buddhism.
